title: "Ratio test and power series"

## The ratio test

For many sequences it may be hard to know whether the corresponding series converge. Fortunately, there are several criteria that can help. Here we focus on the **ratio test**, which shows that a series can often be compared to a geometric series—whose convergence behavior we understand well.^[There are other tests. One you may have discovered in earlier exercises is the **integral test**. Another is **D’Alembert’s criterion**. For our purposes here, the ratio test suffices.]


::: {#thm-ratio}
**Theorem (Ratio test).**
Let $\{a_n\}$ be a sequence with $a_n\neq 0$ eventually.
1. If $\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right|=L<1$, then $\sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n$ converges (in fact absolutely).
2. If $\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right|=L>1$ or the limit is $\infty$, then $\sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n$ diverges.
:::

::: {.callout-tip title="Proof" collapse="true"}

**(i)** Suppose
$$
\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right|\to L
\quad\text{with }L<1.
$$
Then there exist a number $r\in(0,1)$ and an index $N$ such that for all $n\ge N$,
$$
\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right|<r.
$$
Hence, iterating,
$$
|a_{N+1}|<|a_N|\,r,\qquad
|a_{N+2}|<|a_N|\,r^2,\qquad \ldots,\qquad
|a_{N+k}|<|a_N|\,r^k.
$$
Therefore, for any $\ell\ge 1$,
$$
\sum_{k=1}^{\ell}|a_{N+k}|
\le |a_N|\sum_{k=1}^{\ell} r^k.
$$
Since $\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} r^k$ converges, the comparison test implies that
$\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}|a_{N+k}|$ converges. Consequently,
$$
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}|a_n|
=
\sum_{n=1}^{N}|a_n|+\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}|a_{N+k}|
$$
converges, so $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n$ converges absolutely (hence converges).

**(ii)** If
$$
\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right|=L>1
\quad\text{or}\quad
\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right|=\infty,
$$
then for all sufficiently large $n$ we have $|a_{n+1}|>|a_n|$. In particular,
$|a_n|$ cannot tend to $0$, so $a_n\nrightarrow 0$. By the term test for divergence
(Theorem $\ref{th:conv}$), the series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n$ cannot converge.

:::


## Power series and convergence

A **power series** has the form
$$
\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n x^n.
$$

Example:
$$
\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n!}
$$
converges for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$ (ratio test gives limit $0$).

### Convergence interval

::: {#thm-interval}
**Theorem (Convergence propagates inward).**
For a power series $\sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n x^n$:
1. If it converges at $x=b\neq 0$, then it converges for all $|x|<|b|$.
2. If it diverges at $x=b$, then it diverges for all $|x|>|b|$.
:::

### Radius of convergence

::: {#thm-radius}
**Theorem (Radius of convergence).**
For $\sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n (x-a)^n$, exactly one holds:
1. it converges only at $x=a$;
2. it converges for all $x$;
3. there exists $R>0$ such that it converges if $|x-a|<R$ and diverges if $|x-a|>R$.
The number $R$ is the **radius of convergence**.
:::
